Award.AwardTitle: United States Representation in the International Arctic Science Committee (IASC): 2011-2012
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will continue and augment US representation to the International Arctic Science Committee (IASC) through some salary support to the US VP, Jackie Grebmeier, and travel support for both Jackie and US working group members to attend IASC and related meetings. The proposal will also allow Sara Bowden to provide full time support to three of the five IASC working groups. IASC is currently undergoing internal restructuring and revitalizing in response to a recent external review. The 10 US working group members ? two per disciplinary area of Marine, Atmosphere, Terrestrial, Cryosphere, and Social Science ? have recently attended their first IASC meeting in Potsdam and join an international team purposed with the task of synthesizing, coordinating, and, to a small extent, supporting broadly interdisciplinary, international research in the Arctic. The proposal requests travel funds for the working groups members to allow them to meet biannually and advance the IASC scientific agenda.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PI Grebmeier was the US delegate to the International Arctic Science Committee (IASC) and one of four Vice-Presidents on the IASC Executive Committee (Ex Com) since 2006 that serves as a Board of Directors to oversee the IASC Secretariat and to work on the behalf of the 23 IASC member countries throughout the year. As the U.S. IASC delegate and a Vice-President during that period, she was involved in all major issues and decisions within the organization. IASC has updated its structure, including initiating five working groups (WG): cryosphere, atmosphere, terrestrial, marine, and social and human. The role of IASC is to facilitate international science planning and collaboration in the Arctic. The primary function of the WGs is to encourage and support science-led international programs by offering opportunities for planning and coordination, and by facilitating communication and access to facilities. Each WG is composed of up to two scientists from each IASC member country, appointed by the national adhering bodies. The members are experts in their field, with an international reputation and from different scientific disciplines so that the full range of Arctic research is represented in the WGs. Though the WGs are disciplinary, they also address cross-cutting science questions by initiating activities which involve at least three WGs.

The US IASC WG held meetings during the spring Arctic Science Summit Week (ASSW) 2014 in Helsinki, Finland and PI Grebmeier organized the fall 2014 IASC WG team meeting with US agency representatives prior to the joint US Polar Research Board-IASC WG meeting associated with the annual PRB fall meting. She assisted the US IASC WG team in international activities as the US IASC Council member. During the course of this grant PI Grebmeier annually attended two PRB meetings, two IASC Executive Committee meetings, and the IASC Council meeting held during the annual ASSW, including in Krakow, Poland (2013) and Helsinki, Finland (2014). PI Grebmeier was awarded the 2015 IASC Medal during the ASSW meeting in Toyama, Japan this past spring in recognition for her scientific achievements and long-term efforts for international science planning efforts. She has worked extensively towards this objective in both the IASC forum (2006-2014) as well as chairing the Pacific Arctic Group (PAG, 2012-2014), a network of scientists and managers working in the Pacific Arctic. PI Grebmeier stepped down as the US IASC Council delegate in April 2014, although she continued to assist the new US IASC Council member (Dr. Larry Hinzman, University of Alaska Fairbanks) with transition activities related to the US IASC working groups until the end of this grant. She facilitated travel for all US IASC WG members through fall 2014.
